Rep. Luis V. Gutiérrez (D-IL) got news late today that Puerto Rican political prisoner Oscar López Rivera was granted clemency by President Barack Obama and it will take effect, unconditionally, in 120 days. The following is a statement from Rep. Luis V. Gutiérrez http://bit.ly/2iEGnuS:  "I am overjoyed and overwhelmed with emotion. Oscar is a friend, a mentor, and family to me and he and his brother José have been friends and mentors for my entire adult life. There were times when hope was hard to find but my wife Soraida always had faith that this day would come.  Now it is clear that Oscar will rejoin his family and be able to walk free among the Puerto Rican people.  "Thank you, President Obama, thank you on behalf of millions of Puerto Ricans on the Island and around the world.  Thank you from Oscar's family and friends in Chicago.  The international campaign of religious leaders, elected officials, Nobel Prize winners, and ordinary people of faith and good conscience has led to this day.  We have had our prayers answered.  "Releasing Oscar López Rivera back to his homeland and his people is a step towards peace and reconciliation and is being celebrated by Puerto Ricans of all political stripes, classes, colors and geographies.  He is a national hero no less significant than Roberto Clemente or any leader we have ever had.  It will be a blessed day when I can walk and talk with my friend in the fresh air, far from prison walls, and I am so looking forward to that day."

Chicago is a 4th Amendment City and Damn Proud of It  The City of Chicago should not be handing over people or their information in the absence of a warrant. This is about the 4th Amendment. This is about protecting the city from liability and lawsuits. This is about human rights and this is about common sense.  This is about sensible policing.  Chicago is not a “sanctuary” for criminals.  Nobody gets sanctuary if they commit a crime or hurt someone or shoot someone.  People around the country think that in cities like Chicago, if an undocumented immigrant shoots someone in cold blood they don’t go to jail. They really believe that.   What we are saying is that we will take care of the crime that is committed in our city.  We will jail and set free people based on their violations of our laws, not the civil code of the US. That’s your job, Mr. ICE.  That’s your job, Mr. President.   If the federal government wants someone, they should do what cops and governments do under our Constitution and the 4th Amendment and its bar of “unreasonable search and seizure” and "probable cause" for warrants.  Go before a judge, make you case and get a warrant. Chicago is a 4th Amendment city and damn proud of it.  [Excerpt from remarks of Rep. Gutierrez, as prepared for delivery, today in Chicago at a press conference and community meeting at the Instituto de Progreso Latino with Senator Dick Durbin, Alderman Danny Solis and Mayor Rahm Emanuel. (Racine, Wisconsin | Sábado, 1ro de abril, 3pm-5pm)   Los constituyentes del presidente de la Cámara de Representantes Paul Ryan exigen que bloquee el presupuesto militarista y racista de Trump, defienda a las familias inmigrantes e invierta en el cuidado de salud, buenos empleos y la educación  Foro comunitario viene mientras líderes nacionales del movimiento para los derechos de los inmigrantes se reúnen en el distrito de Ryan para anunciar la huelga general del 1ro de mayo   Quién: Voces de la Frontera, La Red Nacional de Jornaleros y Jornaleras (conocido como NDLON por sus siglas en inglés), El Movimiento para una Reforma Migratoria Justa (FIRM), constituyentes del presidente de la Cámara de Representantes Paul Ryan, líderes nacionales del movimiento para los derechos de los inmigrantes y trabajadores, el congresista Luís Gutiérrez,oficiales electos del distrito de Ryan incluyendo el senador estatal Robert Wirch y el representante estatal Cory Mason  Qué: Foro Comunitario: ¿dónde está Paul Ryan?, anuncio de la Huelga Nacional del 1ro de Mayo para los Derechos de los Inmigrantes y Refugiados  Cuándo: Sábado, 1ro de abril, 3pm-5pm  Dónde: Centro Comunitario Dr. John Bryant, 601 S. 21st St., Racine, WI 53403  RACINE, WISCONSIN - El sábado 1ro de abril, líderes nacionales del movimiento para los derechos de los inmigrantes y trabajadores se unirán a los constituyentes del presidente de la Cámara de Representantes nacional Paul Ryan, para pedirle a Ryan que bloquee el presupuesto de Trump, que quiere financiar la guerra y las deportaciones, y en su lugar proveer fondos para el cuidad de salud, buenos empleos y la educación pública. El foro comunitario viene mientras representantes de más de doce organizaciones que luchan para los derechos de los inmigrantes y los derechos civiles y uniones se reúnen para en el distrito de Ryan para planear la huelga general del 1ro de mayo. Gutiérrez (D-Ill.) on Thursday responded to Senate President Thomas Rivera Schatz, who used the masculine pronoun “señor” repeatedly to describe Ana Matosantos, one of the female members of the federally appointed Financial Oversight and Management Board.   On Wednesday, during a radio interview with journalist Carmen Jovet on NotiUno 610 AM, Rivera Schatz used what was widely regarded as a homophobic slur from a “politician and [political] party” with a record of hostility toward the lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender LGBT community, Gutiérrez charged.   “This crossed a line,” Gutiérrez said. “This wasn’t an accident or a slip of the tongue, this fits the pattern of how pro-statehooders relate to the LGBT community -- namely: with hostility and homophobia. What matters is that one of the most senior leaders of the Puerto Rican government thinks it is OK to talk this way and it reveals a lot about the conservative politics of the pro-statehood movement. Making fun of someone’s sexual orientation or gender identity is never okay -- in Puerto Rico or anywhere else. I am the last one to support anything the oversight board is up to, but homophobic remarks? That is beneath the dignity even of the statehooders and makes President Trump look mature and well-adjusted by comparison.”   Congressman Gutiérrez recently spoke on the federal House floor to warn his fellow Democrats that statehooders in Puerto Rico are not political allies.   Gutiérrez has been fighting in Congress against the imposition of the Financial Oversight and Management Board of which Matosantos is a member. The eight-member oversight board was put in place as part of the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA), Congressional legislation passed in 2016 to help the island government tackle its massive public debt burden and begin to reverse Puerto Rico’s economic decline. Matosantos was an appointee nominated by Democrats in Congress.   Late last month, Gutiérrez spoke on the House fl oor about the June 11 plebiscite in Puerto Rico, where 97 percent of the voters supported statehood, but only 23 percent of the voters “actually took the time to vote.”   He warned Democrats that “those who are peddling the fantasy of statehood sometimes call themselves Democrats, but we should all beware of an elephant in donkey clothing.”   Gutiérrez conceded, sarcastically, that the 97 percent result was “pretty impressive,” but said the results represent “the kind of numbers that would make Vladimir Putin jealous and Saddam Hussein green with envy if he were not so dead.”   “And the reason why the statehooders got 97 percent of the vote was pretty much the same reason as those guys too: only one political party participated,” Gutiérrez said. “All the other parties thought the election was so rigged and so pre-determined for the outcome the sponsors wanted that it was not even worth taking part. And the vast majority of Puerto Ricans agreed. Only 23 percent of the people voted. Seventy-seven percent thought it was not worth their time to participate in what was basically an elaborate publicity stunt for the ruling party. And they were absolutely right.”   Gutiérrez noted that Resident Commissioner Jenniff er González ran on the statehood party ticket, is a Republican and “a proud supporter of Donald Trump,” and that the head of the governor’s offi ce in Washington is a Republican operative who ran the “’Latino Partnership for Conservative Principles,’ infamous for its constant bashing of President Obama.”   “So instead of spending money to help children whose schools are closing, or fi x roads that are falling apart, or pay doctors enough to prevent them from moving to Florida, it seems the entire Puerto Rican government is now dedicated to pursuing the unlikely chance of statehood,” Gutiérrez said. “It is certainly useful as a distraction from what the governor and his DC operatives are actually doing.”   The U.S. Congressman, who was born in Chicago to parents who were migrants from Puerto Rico, has lived, worked and gone to school in Puerto Rico at various times in his life.   “I have said before and will say again, I plan to be buried on the beautiful island of Puerto Rico some day and I hope that when that happens, I will be in a free and sovereign nation that has thrown off the yoke of colonialism and dependence on an overseas master, just as this country -- the country of my birth -- has done,” Gutiérrez said.   “In the meantime, I think it is important to warn my fellow Democrats that they should no more get in bed with the statehooders than with any other group of right-wing conservatives with an agenda.”

This afternoon, my colleagues in the Congressional Hispanic Caucus and I walked to the Senate side of the Capitol to meet (unannounced) with Sen. Chuck Schumer in a last minute appeal for the Dream Act before we leave town.  I am very proud of my colleagues (list below) and I think we had a good, frank discussion with the Senator.  We did not change the outcome of the day, which is that the Dream Act will not be passed today or this year.  But I believe Democrats are on the same page and set up well for a resumed fight in January when the budget and spending issues will be reopened.  We cannot wait for the Dream Act because Dreamers with DACA are losing their status, losing their jobs, and we fear, some are losing hope.  But the CHC is committed and ready to keep fighting.
